instruction: Make up a bedtime story for a three year old.
response:
Once upon a time, in a land far, far away, there lived a little bear named Benny. Benny was the smallest bear in his family, and he loved nothing more than to explore the great wide world around him.

Every night, Benny's mommy would tuck him into bed and tell him a story about the incredible adventures he would go on when he was all grown up. Benny would close his eyes and let his imagination take him to magical places, places where he could climb the tallest mountains, swim the deepest rivers, and explore the darkest caves.

One night, after his mommy had finished her story, Benny couldn't fall asleep. He was so excited about all the adventures he was going to have that he just couldn't wait to grow up. So, he decided to sneak out of his bed and go on an adventure of his own.

Benny tiptoed out of his room and into the dark, quiet forest. The moon was shining bright, and Benny could see all the trees and animals around him. He walked and walked, taking in everything he saw, and soon he found himself at the foot of a tall mountain.

Without hesitation, Benny began to climb. Higher and higher he went, until he reached the tippy-top. From there, he could see the whole world. It was so beautiful and so peaceful, and Benny realized that he didn't need to grow up to go on adventures. He could have them right now, at this very moment.

So, Benny climbed back down the mountain and made his way back home. When he snuggled into his bed, his mommy was there, waiting for him. Benny told her all about his adventure, and she smiled and gave him a hug.

"Every night is an adventure, Benny," she said. "As long as you believe in yourself and follow your dreams, you can do anything."

And with that, Benny closed his eyes and fell into a deep, peaceful sleep, ready for a new adventure in the morning.
generated_response:
When the sun yawned and slipped behind the trees, the sky put on a soft purple sweater. In a snug little burrow at the edge of the meadow, a small bunny named Binky brushed his whiskers, wiggled his nose, and climbed into bed.

His blanket felt warm and fluffy. His pillow was as soft as a cloud. A tiny nightlight shaped like a carrot glowed like a friendly firefly. Mama Bunny tucked him in and kissed his forehead. ‚ÄúGood night, my little hop,‚Äù she whispered. ‚ÄúSleep tight.‚Äù

Binky looked around his cozy room. He liked to say good night to all his favorite things. ‚ÄúGood night, pillow. Good night, blanket. Good night, little carrot light,‚Äù he whispered. His ears wiggled. The night was quiet and kind.

Outside the window, the leaves went shhh, shhh as the gentle wind tiptoed through the trees. A little owl said hoo, hoo, hoo from a branch. Far away, crickets sang a tiny lullaby: chirp-chirp, chirp-chirp.

Binky felt very calm. He held his soft toy carrot and yawned a big bunny yawn. ‚ÄúAaahhh.‚Äù Then, a twinkle peeped in at the window. A small star had come to say hello.

‚ÄúHello, Binky,‚Äù the star whispered in a voice as soft as a feather. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time for the world to get cozy. Would you like to say good night with me?‚Äù

Binky nodded and blinked his sleepy eyes. The star shone a gentle glow over the meadow.

‚ÄúLook,‚Äù the star said. ‚ÄúI see five little fireflies dancing slow.‚Äù

Binky counted them on his paw. ‚ÄúOne‚Ä¶ two‚Ä¶ three‚Ä¶ four‚Ä¶ five.‚Äù The fireflies drifted like tiny lanterns. ‚ÄúGood night, little fireflies. Glow soft, glow slow,‚Äù Binky whispered.

‚ÄúNow I see four big leaves resting on a branch,‚Äù said the star.

Binky counted again. ‚ÄúOne‚Ä¶ two‚Ä¶ three‚Ä¶ four.‚Äù The leaves were still and happy. ‚ÄúGood night, big leaves. Rest easy, rest easy,‚Äù he said.

‚ÄúI see three fluffy clouds floating like pillows,‚Äù the star said.

Binky smiled. ‚ÄúOne‚Ä¶ two‚Ä¶ three.‚Äù The clouds looked comfy and kind. ‚ÄúGood night, fluffy clouds. Float quiet, float light.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd there are two owls with round, bright eyes,‚Äù said the star.

‚ÄúHoo,‚Äù whispered Binky. ‚ÄúOne‚Ä¶ two.‚Äù The owls tucked their heads under their wings. ‚ÄúGood night, owls. Hoo-hoo, sleep true.‚Äù

The star twinkled. ‚ÄúAnd now, just one moon, big and gentle.‚Äù

Binky looked at the round, friendly moon. ‚ÄúGood night, Moon. Shine soft, shine bright.‚Äù

The meadow felt sleepy. The trees felt sleepy. Even the little stream that liked to giggle went hush, hush, hush. Binky felt his own eyes getting heavier and heavier, like pebbles resting in warm sand.

‚ÄúLet‚Äôs tuck in our last good nights,‚Äù the star whispered. ‚ÄúGood night, little ladybug under your leaf. Good night, tiny snail in your shell. Good night, soft grass and quiet path. Good night, sweet burrow and safe, snug bed.‚Äù

Binky snuggled deeper into his blanket. He breathed in, slow like a turtle. He breathed out, slow like a cloud. In, and out. In, and out. The star‚Äôs light was gentle, like a lullaby you could see.

‚ÄúShhh,‚Äù said the wind.
‚ÄúHoo,‚Äù said the owl.
‚ÄúChirp,‚Äù sang the crickets.
‚ÄúGood night,‚Äù whispered the moon.

‚ÄúGood night,‚Äù Binky whispered back. His whiskers were still. His nose was quiet. His paws were warm.

The star hummed a tiny song.

Close your eyes, my little friend,
Day is done, the dreams begin.
Safe and snug till morning light,
Good night, good night, sleep tight.

Binky thought of soft clover and warm sunshine and hopping slowly through a meadow that felt like a hug. He thought of Mama Bunny‚Äôs kiss and the carrot nightlight‚Äôs friendly glow. He did a last small yawn. ‚ÄúAaahh,‚Äù he whispered.

‚ÄúSleep well, Binky,‚Äù said the star. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll keep watch with the moon and the owls and the fireflies. We‚Äôll be here, shining and humming, all night long.‚Äù

And so the little burrow was calm and still. The star winked once more and rested high above. The meadow dreamed. The moon smiled. And Binky the bunny, safe and loved, drifted into sweet, cozy sleep.

Good night, little one. Sleep tight. The world is quiet. The stars are bright.

instruction: Set up an environment for serving a Python web application
response:
Sure! Here are the steps to set up an environment for serving a Python web application:

1. Install a web server: You'll need to install a web server like Nginx or Apache to serve your Python web application.

2. Install and activate a Python virtual environment: It is recommended to install your application dependencies in a virtual environment rather than globally on the server. You can install the `virtualenv` package using `pip` and then create and activate a virtual environment for your application.

3. Install dependencies: Install any dependencies required for your web application using `pip` inside the activated virtual environment.

4. Configure the web server: The way you configure your web server will depend on whether you are using Nginx, Apache, or another server. You'll typically need to create a server block or virtual host, and configure the server to pass requests to your application using a protocol like WSGI or FastCGI.

5. Deploy your Python web application: Once your web server is configured, you'll need to deploy your Python web application to the server. This typically involves copying your application code to the server, and potentially making some changes to your application configuration to get it working in the new environment.

6. Test your deployment: Make sure your application is working correctly by testing it in a web browser. Ensure that all routes are working as expected and that there are no errors in the server logs.

That's it! With these steps, you should be able to set up an environment for serving a Python web application successfully.
generated_response:
Below is a practical, production-ready baseline for serving a Python web application on a Linux VM (Ubuntu 22.04+). It works for Flask/Django (WSGI) and FastAPI/Starlette (ASGI). If you have a different OS, hosting provider, or framework, tell me and I‚Äôll tailor the steps.

High-level architecture
- App code runs in a Python virtual environment.
- A production app server handles Python requests:
  - WSGI (Flask, Django): Gunicorn.
  - ASGI (FastAPI, Starlette, Django 3.1+ async): Uvicorn or Gunicorn with uvicorn workers.
- Nginx acts as a reverse proxy, TLS terminator, static file server, and request buffer.
- systemd runs and restarts your services.
- Environment variables hold secrets and config (no secrets in code).

1) Decide your Python interface
- Flask/Django: WSGI app object, often named app or application. Example target: myapp.wsgi:application or myapp.app:app.
- FastAPI/Starlette: ASGI app object, usually called app. Example target: myapp.main:app.

2) Prepare the server (Ubuntu)
- Create a non-root user and harden SSH (optional but recommended).
- Update and install dependencies:
  - sudo apt update && sudo apt -y upgrade
  - sudo apt -y install python3 python3-venv python3-pip build-essential nginx git ufw
  - Optional: for TLS via Let‚Äôs Encrypt: sudo apt -y install certbot python3-certbot-nginx
- Firewall (UFW):
  - sudo ufw allow OpenSSH
  - sudo ufw allow 'Nginx Full'
  - sudo ufw enable

3) Create project layout and user
- Create a dedicated user (skip if you already have one): sudo adduser --system --group --home /srv/myapp myapp
- Create directories:
  - sudo mkdir -p /srv/myapp/{app,run,logs,env}
  - sudo chown -R myapp:myapp /srv/myapp
- Optional: lock down permissions to least required.

4) Get your code onto the server
- Example with git:
  - sudo -u myapp -H bash -lc "cd /srv/myapp/app && git clone https://your.repo/url ."
- Or SFTP/rsync your code into /srv/myapp/app.

5) Create and populate a virtual environment
- sudo -u myapp -H python3 -m venv /srv/myapp/venv
- sudo -u myapp -H /srv/myapp/venv/bin/pip install --upgrade pip wheel
- sudo -u myapp -H /srv/myapp/venv/bin/pip install -r /srv/myapp/app/requirements.txt
- Django-specific:
  - Set DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE in env (see step 8).
  - Collect static files: sudo -u myapp -H /srv/myapp/venv/bin/python /srv/myapp/app/manage.py collectstatic --noinput
  - Run migrations: sudo -u myapp -H /srv/myapp/venv/bin/python /srv/myapp/app/manage.py migrate

6) Smoke-test the app locally (loopback)
- Find your app import target:
  - WSGI (Flask/Django): something like myapp.wsgi:application or myapp:app
  - ASGI (FastAPI): something like myapp.main:app
- Test on 127.0.0.1:8000:
  - WSGI with Gunicorn:
    - sudo -u myapp -H /srv/myapp/venv/bin/gunicorn -b 127.0.0.1:8000 myapp.wsgi:application
  - ASGI with Uvicorn:
    - sudo -u myapp -H /srv/myapp/venv/bin/uvicorn myapp.main:app --host 127.0.0.1 --port 8000
- Curl it from the server: curl -i http://127.0.0.1:8000

7) Create a systemd service (process manager)
- Create a unit file at /etc/systemd/system/myapp.service with root permissions.
- For WSGI (Gunicorn over Unix socket):
  - [Unit]
    Description=Gunicorn for myapp
    After=network.target

  - [Service]
    User=myapp
    Group=myapp
    WorkingDirectory=/srv/myapp/app
    EnvironmentFile=/srv/myapp/env/app.env
    RuntimeDirectory=myapp
    ExecStart=/srv/myapp/venv/bin/gunicorn myapp.wsgi:application --workers 3 --bind unix:/srv/myapp/run/gunicorn.sock --access-logfile - --error-logfile -
    Restart=always
    RestartSec=3
    TimeoutStopSec=30

  - [Install]
    WantedBy=multi-user.target
- For ASGI (Gunicorn with Uvicorn workers over Unix socket):
  - ExecStart=/srv/myapp/venv/bin/gunicorn myapp.main:app -k uvicorn.workers.UvicornWorker --workers 3 --bind unix:/srv/myapp/run/gunicorn.sock --access-logfile - --error-logfile -
- Or ASGI with Uvicorn directly:
  - ExecStart=/srv/myapp/venv/bin/uvicorn myapp.main:app --uds /srv/myapp/run/uvicorn.sock --workers 3
- Reload and start:
  - sudo systemctl daemon-reload
  - sudo systemctl enable --now myapp
  - Check logs: sudo journalctl -u myapp -f

8) Configure environment variables and secrets
- Create /srv/myapp/env/app.env owned by myapp:myapp and mode 600.
- Put settings like:
  - SECRET_KEY=change-me
  - DATABASE_URL=postgresql+psycopg2://user:pass@dbhost:5432/dbname
  - DEBUG=False
  - For Django: DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE=myapp.settings.production
- systemd EnvironmentFile line in step 7 will load these; restart after changes:
  - sudo systemctl restart myapp

9) Nginx reverse proxy
- Create /etc/nginx/sites-available/myapp with something like:
  - upstream myapp {
      server unix:/srv/myapp/run/gunicorn.sock;
    }
  - server {
      listen 80;
      server_name yourdomain.com www.yourdomain.com;

      client_max_body_size 25m;

      # If using WebSockets (ASGI), keep these:
      location / {
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection $connection_upgrade;
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_pass http://myapp;
      }

      # Static files (optional; adjust paths)
      location /static/ {
        alias /srv/myapp/app/static/;
        access_log off;
        expires 7d;
      }

      # Media/uploads (if any)
      location /media/ {
        alias /srv/myapp/app/media/;
        expires 7d;
      }
    }
- Enable the site:
  - sudo ln -s /etc/nginx/sites-available/myapp /etc/nginx/sites-enabled/myapp
  - sudo nginx -t
  - sudo systemctl reload nginx
- Test HTTP on the domain before enabling TLS.

10) TLS with Let‚Äôs Encrypt
- Ensure DNS A/AAAA records point to your server.
- Run:
  - sudo certbot --nginx -d yourdomain.com -d www.yourdomain.com
- Certbot will install the certificate, redirect HTTP‚ÜíHTTPS, and set up auto-renewal.

11) Database, migrations, and connections
- Managed DB recommended for production; or install Postgres locally:
  - sudo apt -y install postgresql postgresql-contrib
  - Create DB and user; store credentials in DATABASE_URL in app.env.
- Apply migrations:
  - Django: manage.py migrate
  - Flask/FastAPI with Alembic: alembic upgrade head

12) Static files and uploads
- Django: run collectstatic; serve via Nginx (as above) or use WhiteNoise for simplicity (then Nginx location /static is optional).
- Flask/FastAPI: build static assets if applicable; place under app/static and map with Nginx alias.

13) Background workers (optional)
- For tasks (Celery + Redis/RabbitMQ):
  - Install Redis: sudo apt -y install redis
  - Create systemd units for celery and celery-beat:
    - ExecStart=/srv/myapp/venv/bin/celery -A myapp.celery_app worker --loglevel=INFO
    - ExecStart=/srv/myapp/venv/bin/celery -A myapp.celery_app beat --loglevel=INFO
  - Enable and start them.

14) Logging and monitoring
- Gunicorn logs sent to journald via --access-logfile - and --error-logfile -; view with journalctl.
- Nginx logs: /var/log/nginx/access.log and error.log.
- Consider:
  - Log rotation: Ubuntu has logrotate configured for Nginx; journald rotates by policy.
  - Health checks: a /health endpoint and uptime monitoring.
  - Metrics/APM: Prometheus exporters, Sentry, or a hosted service.

15) Security basics
- Keep system updated: enable unattended-upgrades.
- Principle of least privilege: non-root user owns files; only Nginx listens on 80/443.
- Don‚Äôt run DEBUG in production.
- Set secure cookies, CSRF protection (Django/Flask-WTF), and allowed hosts.
- Restrict file permissions on /srv/myapp/env/app.env (chmod 600).
- Consider Fail2ban for SSH/Nginx.

16) Deploy and update workflow
- Pull latest code into /srv/myapp/app (or use CI/CD).
- Reinstall dependencies if requirements changed:
  - sudo -u myapp -H /srv/myapp/venv/bin/pip install -r requirements.txt
- Run migrations and collectstatic as needed.
- Reload the app:
  - sudo systemctl restart myapp
- Zero-downtime reloads are possible with Gunicorn (USR2) but systemd restart is often fine for small apps.

Optional: containerized (Docker) approach
- Build an image with Gunicorn and your app; run behind Nginx or Caddy.
- Minimal outline:
  - Base: python:3.11-slim
  - Copy code, install requirements, create non-root user
  - CMD: gunicorn myapp.wsgi:application -b 0.0.0.0:8000 -w 3
- Use docker-compose to run:
  - web (your app)
  - reverse-proxy (Nginx or Caddy)
  - db/redis if needed
- Benefits: consistent builds, easy rollbacks; Costs: extra complexity.

Notes per framework
- Flask: ensure you don‚Äôt use the built-in dev server in production; target app object for Gunicorn (e.g., myapp:app).
- Django: use myapp.wsgi:application; set ALLOWED_HOSTS, collectstatic; optionally use WhiteNoise or Nginx for static.
- FastAPI/Starlette: use ASGI. If you need WebSockets, keep the Upgrade/Connection headers in Nginx.

If you share your framework, OS, and whether you prefer VM or Docker, I can provide an exact set of commands and configs tailored to your app (including a ready-to-paste systemd unit and Nginx server block with your module names).

Therapy can provide a safe space to process these events and work through the emotions that accompany them.

instruction:
Write a news article about the event.
The opening ceremony of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics was held at the National Stadium.
response:
Tokyo 2020 Olympics Officially Kicks Off With a Dazzling Opening Ceremony

The long-anticipated Tokyo 2020 Olympics officially kicked off with a dazzling opening ceremony held at the National Stadium. The ceremony, which was delayed by a year due to the COVID-19 pandemic, was a true celebration of hope, resilience and unity.

The event began with the traditional lighting of the Olympic Cauldron, which was followed by an impressive display of fireworks that lit up the night sky. As the world watched, athletes from all corners of the globe paraded into the stadium, proudly waving their national flags.

The audience was treated to an array of traditional Japanese performances, including taiko drumming, kabuki theatre, and colorful dance routines. Stunning visual displays and cutting-edge special effects were also on show, highlighting the country's rich cultural heritage and technological advancements.

Despite the challenges and uncertainties brought on by the pandemic, the opening ceremony of the Tokyo 2020 Olympics was a true testament to the enduring spirit of the Olympic Games. It brought people from all over the world together, even if only virtually, to celebrate the start of this incredible event. Let the games begin!
generated_response:
Tokyo 2020 Olympics open with a restrained, poignant ceremony at National Stadium

Tokyo ‚Äî The Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games officially opened Friday night at Japan‚Äôs National Stadium, a ceremony that blended artistry and technology with a sober acknowledgment of the global pandemic that delayed the event by a year.

Held in largely empty stands due to COVID-19 restrictions, the two-hour spectacle introduced the world to the Games‚Äô theme of unity and resilience. Performers traced Japan‚Äôs cultural heritage and the journey of athletes who trained in isolation, while a moment of silence honored lives lost during the pandemic and other tragedies.

The show‚Äôs most striking visual came from a swarm of synchronized drones that assembled into a luminous globe above the stadium, symbolizing worldwide togetherness. Another highlight paid playful homage to a quintessential Olympic feature: actors raced through rapid-fire transformations of sport pictograms, mirroring the icons seen on signage and broadcasts.

Tradition and protocol anchored the evening. Emperor Naruhito declared the Games open, and International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach greeted competitors, emphasizing solidarity after an unprecedented postponement. The updated Olympic motto‚ÄîFaster, Higher, Stronger ‚Äî Together‚Äîechoed throughout.

The Parade of Nations featured masked, smaller delegations, with teams allowed to designate two flag bearers to promote gender equality. The IOC Refugee Olympic Team received warm applause, and the host nation‚Äôs athletes, Team Japan, entered last to sustained cheers from officials and volunteers.

In a finale crafted to resonate far beyond sport, Japanese tennis star Naomi Osaka lit the Olympic cauldron, igniting a flower-like structure that flared to life and signaled the Games‚Äô official start.

Dignitaries in attendance included Emperor Naruhito, Japanese Prime Minister Yoshihide Suga, and IOC leadership, alongside a limited number of invited guests. Outside the venue, small groups of demonstrators gathered, reflecting the public debate over holding the Games amid a state of emergency.

The Tokyo Olympics, featuring thousands of athletes from around the world, will run through August 8 with competition across dozens of sports, including the Olympic debuts of skateboarding, surfing, and sport climbing and the return of baseball/softball. Organizers have emphasized rigorous health protocols throughout, aiming to balance celebration with caution in an extraordinary moment for global sport.

instruction: Identify three characteristics of a monarch butterfly.
response:
1. Distinctive orange and black wings: Monarch butterflies are easily identifiable by their bright orange wings patterned with thick black veins and white spots along the edges. Their wingspan can typically measure between 8.9‚Äì10.2 cm (3¬Ω‚Äì4 inches).

2. Migration: Monarch butterflies are known for their impressive migration patterns. Every year, in North America, they travel thousands of miles from Canada and the United States to overwintering sites in Mexico.

3. Milkweed plant dependence: Monarch caterpillars feed exclusively on the leaves of milkweed plants, making them entirely dependent on this plant for their survival. As adult butterflies, monarchs also get important nutrients from milkweed, but also feed on the nectar of other flowers.
generated_response:
- Bright orange wings with bold black veins and a black border dotted with white spots.
- Famous long-distance migration, with populations in North America traveling thousands of miles to overwinter in central Mexico.
- Caterpillars feed on milkweed and store its cardiac glycosides, making both caterpillars and adults distasteful to many predators.

instruction: Write a Python script to print the first 10 numbers between 1 and 100 that are multiples of 3.
Construct a recipe for banana pancakes
response:
Banana Pancakes Recipe:
Makes 8 to 10 pancakes

Ingredients:
- 1 cup all-purpose flour
- 1 tablespoon sugar
- 2 teaspoons baking powder
- 1/4 teaspoon salt
- 1 ripe banana, mashed
- 1 cup milk
- 2 large eggs
- 1/4 cup melted butter, plus extra for cooking
- 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
- Maple syrup or honey, for serving

Instructions:

1. In a medium bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt.

2. In another bowl, mash the banana until smooth, then mix in the milk, eggs, melted butter, and vanilla extract.

3. Stir the wet mixture into the dry until just combined.

4. Heat a non-stick skillet or griddle over medium heat and melt a little butter in it.

5. Scoop 1/4 cup of the batter into the skillet for each pancake. Cook until the surface is bubbly and the edges start to look set, about 2 to 3 minutes, then flip and cook for another 2 to 3 minutes until cooked through.

6. Serve the pancakes hot with maple syrup or honey drizzled on top. Enjoy!

Note: For an extra burst of flavor, you can add a handful of chopped nuts or chocolate chips to the batter before cooking.
generated_response:
Here‚Äôs a reliable, fluffy banana pancake recipe with options to tweak it to your taste.

Yield: 8 pancakes (serves 2‚Äì3)
Time: 20 minutes

Ingredients
- 2 very ripe bananas, mashed (about 1 cup/240 g)
- 1 cup (125 g) all-purpose flour
- 1 tablespoon sugar (optional, adjust to taste)
- 1 teaspoon baking powder
- 1/2 teaspoon baking soda (optional but helps browning and lift)
- 1/4 teaspoon fine salt
- 1/2‚Äì1 teaspoon ground cinnamon (optional)
- 1 large egg
- 3/4 cup (180 ml) milk (dairy or non-dairy), plus 1‚Äì2 tablespoons if needed
- 1 teaspoon vanilla extract
- 2 tablespoons melted butter or neutral oil, plus more for the pan
- Optional add-ins: 1/3 cup chocolate chips, blueberries, or chopped nuts

Equipment
- Mixing bowls, whisk or fork, measuring cups/spoons
- Nonstick skillet or griddle, spatula

Instructions
1. Mash bananas in a bowl until mostly smooth.
2. Whisk in the egg, milk, vanilla, and melted butter/oil.
3. In a separate bowl, combine flour, sugar, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and cinnamon.
4. Add dry ingredients to the wet. Stir gently until just combined; a few small lumps are fine. If the batter seems too thick, add milk 1 tablespoon at a time. Let rest 5 minutes.
5. Heat a lightly oiled skillet over medium heat. When a drop of water sizzles, it‚Äôs ready.
6. Pour about 1/4 cup batter per pancake. Cook until bubbles form and edges look set, 2‚Äì3 minutes. Flip and cook 1‚Äì2 minutes more until golden and cooked through.
7. Keep finished pancakes warm in a low oven (about 200¬∞F/95¬∞C) while you finish the batch.
8. Serve with butter, maple syrup, sliced bananas, yogurt, peanut butter, or your favorite toppings.

Tips for success
- Use very ripe, spotty bananas for the best sweetness and flavor.
- Don‚Äôt overmix; it keeps pancakes tender and fluffy.
- Medium heat prevents burning before the centers cook.
- For extra fluffiness, separate the egg and whisk the white to soft peaks, then fold in at the end.

Variations and substitutions
- Vegan: Replace egg with 1 tablespoon ground flax mixed with 3 tablespoons water (rest 5 minutes). Use plant milk and oil instead of butter. Increase baking powder to 1.5 teaspoons.
- Gluten-free: Use a 1:1 gluten-free flour blend, or 3/4 cup oat flour + 1/4 cup almond flour; let the batter rest 10 minutes.
- Whole wheat: Use white whole wheat flour; add 1‚Äì2 tablespoons extra milk if needed.
- Protein boost: Add 2 tablespoons protein powder and a splash more milk to keep batter pourable.

Storage and reheating
- Refrigerate leftovers up to 3 days.
- Freeze up to 2 months with parchment between pancakes. Reheat in a toaster or 350¬∞F/175¬∞C oven for 5‚Äì8 minutes.

Approximate nutrition (per pancake, 1/8 of recipe, without toppings): about 130‚Äì150 calories.

instruction: Explain why there is an increase in online shopping.
response:
Online shopping has increased in popularity over recent years for several reasons:

1) Convenience: Online shopping allows consumers to browse and purchase products anytime and anywhere. With busy lifestyles, many people prefer the convenience of shopping from the comfort of their own homes or on their mobile devices rather than driving to a physical store.

2) Greater selection: Online shopping offers a wider range of products and brands. Customers can choose from a variety of sellers and compare prices to get the best deals.

3) Time-saving: Online shopping eliminates the need to physically walk through different stores, stand in long checkout lines, and wait for assistance. This makes it an attractive option for time-starved individuals.

4) Cost-saving: Online retailers have lower overhead costs which allow them to offer lower prices than brick-and-mortar stores. Many also offer free shipping, which can save customers even more money.

5) Customization: Many online retailers allow customers to customize products to their liking. This can include adding names or initials to items or selecting a specific color or design.

Overall, online shopping provides customers with convenience, greater selection, time and cost savings, and customizable options. These benefits have led to a rise in the popularity of online shopping.
generated_response:
Online shopping has grown because a lot of frictions that used to make it inconvenient have been removed, while new technologies and habits have made it more attractive. Key drivers include:

- Convenience and time savings
  - 24/7 access from anywhere, no travel or queues.
  - Streamlined checkout (autofill, digital wallets, one‚Äëclick) reduces effort.
  - Subscriptions and auto‚Äëreplenishment for routine purchases.

- Broader selection and easier discovery
  - Marketplaces aggregate millions of products and sellers, including niche and global items unavailable locally.
  - Search, filters, reviews, and recommendations reduce the ‚Äúsearch cost‚Äù of finding the right product.

- Price transparency and value
  - Instant price comparison across stores increases competition and often lowers prices.
  - Frequent online promotions, dynamic pricing, and couponing appeal to cost‚Äëconscious shoppers.

- Faster, cheaper, and more reliable delivery
  - Investments in fulfillment centers, last‚Äëmile delivery, and route optimization have shortened delivery windows (same‚Äëday/next‚Äëday).
  - Flexible options (curbside pickup, buy‚Äëonline‚Äëpick‚Äëup‚Äëin‚Äëstore) blend online convenience with immediate access.
  - Better tracking and communication reduce uncertainty.

- Improved trust and user experience
  - Secure payments, buyer protections, and easy returns reduce perceived risk.
  - Rich content (photos, video, AR try‚Äëon, size guides) helps buyers make confident decisions.
  - Customer reviews and Q&A build transparency.

- Mobile and social commerce
  - Near‚Äëuniversal smartphone adoption enables impulse and on‚Äëthe‚Äëgo purchases.
  - Social platforms integrating storefronts, influencer content, and livestream shopping turn discovery directly into purchase.

- New payment options
  - Digital wallets and ‚Äúbuy now, pay later‚Äù broaden access and reduce checkout friction.
  - Localized payment methods support cross‚Äëborder purchases.

- Pandemic‚Äëaccelerated habit formation
  - Lockdowns pushed categories like groceries and essentials online, introducing many new users.
  - Habits formed during that period persisted as experiences improved.

- Broader seller adoption and technology
  - Low‚Äëcost e‚Äëcommerce tools (shop builders, drop‚Äëshipping, fulfillment services) make it easy for small businesses to sell online.
  - Data and personalization help merchants target offers and improve conversion.

- Demographics and lifestyle shifts
  - Digital‚Äënative generations prefer online channels.
  - Urbanization, busy schedules, and remote work patterns favor online over in‚Äëstore errands.

- Access and infrastructure
  - Wider internet coverage and faster mobile networks (4G/5G) make online shopping practical in more regions.

Together, these demand- and supply‚Äëside changes have made online shopping faster, safer, cheaper, and more enjoyable for many categories, leading to sustained growth.

instruction: Describe the main antagonist in the movie Ocean's 11.
response: The main antagonist in the movie Ocean's 11 is Terry Benedict, played by actor Andy Garcia. Benedict is a wealthy and powerful casino magnate who owns three of the most prestigious casinos in Las Vegas: The Bellagio, The Mirage and The MGM Grand. He is portrayed as a cold and ruthless individual who will stop at nothing to get what he wants. Throughout the movie, he is a constant obstacle to the protagonists' plan to rob his casinos, using his resources and connections to try and thwart their efforts. He is also depicted as having a romantic relationship with Tess Ocean, the estranged wife of the protagonist Danny Ocean, adding a further layer of tension between him and the group of burglars.
generated_response:
In the 2001 remake of Ocean‚Äôs Eleven, the main antagonist is Terry Benedict, played by Andy Garc√≠a. He‚Äôs the impeccably composed, ruthlessly pragmatic owner of the Bellagio, Mirage, and MGM Grand. Benedict embodies control: he lives by meticulous schedules, runs a fortress-like security operation, and punishes anyone who threatens his casinos‚Äô order and profits. His menace comes from quiet authority more than bluster‚Äîcalm, calculating, and willing to apply pressure without hesitation.

The conflict is both professional and personal. Benedict‚Äôs vault holds the combined takings of his three casinos on fight night‚Äîthe target of Danny Ocean‚Äôs crew‚Äîand he‚Äôs dating Tess (Julia Roberts), Danny‚Äôs ex-wife. That makes Benedict the embodiment of both the system the crew wants to outsmart and the romantic obstacle Danny wants to overcome. He‚Äôs the opposite of Danny: rigid where Danny is improvisational, transactional where Danny is sentimental. When forced to choose between safeguarding his money and Tess, Benedict reveals his priorities, which costs him personally even as he doubles down on vengeance. Though he‚Äôs outwitted by the heist, he remains a potent, relentless adversary.

Note: In the 1960 original, the antagonist figure is different‚ÄîDuke Santos (Cesar Romero), a suave fixer who uncovers the robbery and tries to blackmail the crew.

instruction: Find a metaphor for the term "data storage".
response: One possible metaphor for "data storage" is a vast library. Just as a library contains a wealth of information in books neatly organized and stored on shelves, data storage contains vast amounts of information carefully indexed and stored in servers or external drives. Just as a librarian can retrieve any book from its specific location, data can be quickly and easily retrieved from storage when needed. And just as a library continually adds and updates its collection, data storage must also be regularly maintained and updated to keep up with changing needs and technology.
generated_response: Data storage is a seed vault for memory, keeping fragile knowledge dormant and safe until the moment it‚Äôs needed to sprout.

instruction: Think of some improvement ideas for a movie review website
response:
1. Enhanced User Interaction: Create an interactive and user-friendly interface that displays reviews and ratings in a clear and organized manner, allowing users to easily sort and filter reviews based on their preferences.

2. Community Features: Encourage user participation by adding features such as user profiles, the ability to follow other users, and a comment section for discussing and debating reviews.

3. Multimedia Integration: Incorporate movie trailers, images, and other media content alongside reviews to provide a more immersive experience for users.

4. Advanced Search: Implement advanced search options to enable users to search for movies based on specific criteria such as genre, release date, and language.

5. Personalization: Offer users the ability to customize their experience on the website by saving their favorite movies, creating watchlists, and receiving recommendations based on their interests.

6. Critic Reviews: Include professional critic reviews and ratings, in addition to user reviews, to provide a more complete picture of a movie's critical reception.

7. Mobile App: Develop a mobile app for the website to reach a wider audience and provide a convenient way for users to access movie reviews on-the-go.

8. Movie News and Events: Keep users engaged by providing up-to-date news about upcoming movies, as well as information about film festivals and other movie-related events.
generated_response:
Here are practical improvement ideas, grouped by area. Mix and match based on your goals (engagement, SEO, monetization, community).

- Discovery and navigation
  - Add mood/tone tags (feel-good, slow-burn, bleak, campy) and let users filter by them.
  - Natural-language search (‚Äúfunny sci-fi without gore under 2 hours‚Äù).
  - Smart facets: runtime, content warnings, release window, awards, language, streaming availability.
  - ‚ÄúIf you liked X, try Y‚Äù carousels powered by embeddings (not just genre).
  - Curated entry points: Staff Picks, Year-in-Review, Festival Winners, Hidden Gems.

- Review quality and trust
  - Spoiler-aware reviews: spoiler sections hidden by default; spoiler detection using NLP.
  - Helpfulness voting and quality-score sorting; surface ‚ÄúMost Helpful This Week.‚Äù
  - Verified watch badges (via scrobble integrations or ticket/stream receipts).
  - Rating histograms and sentiment distribution; summarize pros/cons per film.
  - Conflict-of-interest disclosure and visible edit history for reviews.

- Community and engagement
  - Follow users, critics, and lists; social feed of reviews and lists from follows.
  - Gamification: badges (Early Reviewer, Genre Expert), streaks, ‚ÄúReviewer of the Month.‚Äù
  - Community challenges (e.g., Noir November), watch clubs, and collaborative lists.
  - Q&A threads per film (e.g., ‚ÄúIs it OK for kids 10+?‚Äù) with upvoted answers.
  - Watch parties with synchronized chat (integrate with legal streaming embeds).

- Personalization and recommendations
  - Onboarding quiz to seed taste profile; update with every rating.
  - Multi-criteria recs: by vibe, director, pacing, cast chemistry; ‚ÄúSurprise Me‚Äù button.
  - ‚ÄúFinish your taste profile‚Äù nudges (rate 10 more to unlock better recs).
  - Weekly email/app digest: new releases you‚Äôll like + where to watch.

- Search and filters
  - Power filters: exclude tropes or content (no jump scares, no animal harm).
  - Sort by ‚Äúre-watchability,‚Äù ‚Äúending satisfaction,‚Äù ‚Äúpacing,‚Äù using crowd-sourced sliders.
  - Instant search with typo tolerance and synonyms; search within lists and reviews.
  - Compare films side-by-side (ratings, content, runtime, availability).

- Content and editorial
  - Rich movie pages: trailers, stills, quotes, soundtrack, trivia, goofs, parental guide.
  - Awards timeline and festival circuits; release calendar by region.
  - Editorial blog, podcasts, and explainers (e.g., ‚ÄúBest Debut Features of 2024‚Äù).
  - Creator pages (directors/actors) with filmography graphs and themes they explore.

- Where to watch and commerce
  - Streaming availability with region support and alerts when films arrive/leave platforms.
  - Local showtimes/ticketing; price-drop alerts for rentals.
  - Affiliate links (clearly labeled) to buy/rent/stream; compare providers.
  - ‚ÄúWatch next‚Äù queue that syncs to users‚Äô streaming services if permitted.

- Accessibility and inclusivity
  - WCAG AA/AAA: high contrast themes, keyboard navigation, semantic landmarks, ARIA.
  - Alt text for images; transcripts/captions for trailers; dyslexia-friendly mode.
  - Content warnings and triggers; age suitability summaries; filter by intensity.
  - Adjustable text size and line spacing; light/dark/system themes.

- Internationalization and localization
  - Multi-language UI; locale-aware titles and release dates.
  - Auto-translate reviews with ‚Äúview original‚Äù toggle.
  - Region-specific availability and news; right-to-left layout support.
  - Community moderators per language for quality control.

- Performance and SEO
  - Core Web Vitals: image optimization (AVIF/WebP), lazy loading, code splitting, CDN.
  - Server-side rendering/static generation for film and list pages; prefetch routes.
  - Structured data (schema.org Movie, Review, AggregateRating, BreadcrumbList).
  - SEO assets: XML sitemaps per locale, canonical URLs, Open Graph/Twitter cards.
  - Pagination that‚Äôs crawlable (avoid infinite scroll-only).

- Mobile and apps
  - PWA with offline caching of watchlists and recent pages; add to home screen.
  - Native app with push notifications and background sync; deep links into film pages.
  - Poster/barcode scanner to pull up a film instantly (for physical media).
  - Share sheets that generate clean, preview-rich links.

- Notifications and lifecycle
  - Alerts for: new reviews from followed users, release drops, streaming changes, ticket presales.
  - Digest controls (daily/weekly), quiet hours, granular toggles.
  - Post-watch prompts to rate/review with smart reminders.

- Moderation, safety, and trust
  - Report tools with reason categories; community guidelines and visible enforcement.
  - Automated toxicity and spam detection; brigading/outlier monitoring.
  - Transparent moderation logs and yearly trust & safety report.
  - Rate limits and CAPTCHA for suspected bots; email/phone verification tiers.

- Data integrations and APIs
  - Metadata: TMDB/OMDb; scrobble: Trakt; availability: JustWatch; ticketing: Fandango/Atom.
  - Import from IMDb/Letterboxd/Trakt; export your data to CSV/JSON.
  - Public API for lists and ratings (rate limited), plus embeddable widgets.

- Admin and analytics
  - Editorial CMS with preview; contributor roles; merge/duplicate detection for titles.
  - Review moderation queues with ML-prioritized items.
  - Product analytics: funnels, cohort retention, D1/D7/D30, DAU/MAU, SEO growth.
  - A/B testing framework with guardrail metrics (performance, retention).

- Monetization (clearly labeled and user-first)
  - Premium tier: ad-free, advanced stats, early feature access, power filters.
  - Affiliate revenues (streaming, tickets, merch); sponsor spots in newsletters.
  - Ethical native ads tied to context (e.g., film festivals), with disclosure.
  - Data licensing for aggregated insights (never individual PII).

- Unique differentiators to stand out
  - Scene-by-scene ‚Äúemotion arc‚Äù from aggregated reviews (spoiler-safe overview).
  - ‚ÄúVibe Check‚Äù cards: pacing, humor style, bleakness, romance intensity.
  - AI-generated non-spoiler summaries and ‚ÄúBefore You Watch‚Äù quick briefs.
  - ‚ÄúSpill Index‚Äù spoilometer that estimates spoiler risk in a review before you open it.
  - Collaborative ‚ÄúMovie Night Planner‚Äù: pick preferences, schedule, polling, and availability.

- Quick wins vs. bigger bets
  - Quick wins: structured data, rating histogram, spoiler tags, staff picks, content warnings, availability badges, digest emails.
  - Medium: follow system, quality-sorted reviews, mood filters, import watch history, improved SEO/performance.
  - Big bets: advanced recs via embeddings, watch parties, native apps, multi-language community, scene-level emotion arcs.

If you share your current site‚Äôs audience, traffic sources, and goals (e.g., SEO vs. logged-in engagement), I can tailor a prioritized roadmap with expected impact and effort.

instruction:

In summary, the iPhone SE is an affordable, high-performance smartphone with a compact design, great camera, and long battery life. It is an excellent choice for those who want the power of the latest iPhone technology in a smaller package.

instruction: Suggest a good weight loss diet plan.
response:
It is always recommended to consult with a doctor or registered dietitian before making any changes to your diet. Here is a general outline of a healthy weight loss diet plan:

1. Eat a balanced diet that includes fruits, vegetables, lean proteins, whole grains, and healthy fats. Aim for at least five servings of fruits and vegetables each day, and choose whole foods over processed foods whenever possible.

2. Start your day with a healthy breakfast that includes protein, whole grains, and fiber. This will help keep you full and energized throughout the morning.

3. Keep track of portion sizes and try to eat slowly to allow time for your body to feel full.

4. Limit foods that are high in calories, saturated fat, and added sugars, such as fast food, sweets, and soda.

5. Drink plenty of water throughout the day to stay hydrated, and limit sugary drinks and alcohol.

6. Incorporate physical activity into your daily routine. Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity activity each week, as well as muscle-strengthening exercises twice a week.

7. Don‚Äôt skip meals or follow a very low calorie diet, as this can cause your metabolism to slow down and can be harmful to your health. Instead, aim for a slow and steady weight loss of 1-2 pounds per week.

Remember, healthy weight loss is about creating a sustainable lifestyle change, not following a short-term diet. Choose nutritious foods that you enjoy, and make small changes over time to reach your goals.
generated_response:
Here‚Äôs a sustainable, flexible weight-loss plan you can tailor to your preferences, culture, and schedule. It emphasizes a moderate calorie deficit, high protein, high fiber, and mostly whole foods. If you have a medical condition, are pregnant/breastfeeding, or take medications that affect appetite or blood sugar, check with a healthcare professional before starting.

1) Set a realistic calorie target
- Aim for slow, steady loss: about 0.5‚Äì1% of body weight per week.
- Quick estimate of maintenance calories:
  - Body weight (lb) √ó 14‚Äì16, or body weight (kg) √ó 30‚Äì35.
- Create a deficit of 300‚Äì500 calories per day from maintenance.
- As a general safety floor, avoid going below ~1200 kcal/day for most women or ~1500 kcal/day for most men without medical supervision.

2) Set simple macro targets
- Protein: 1.6‚Äì2.2 g per kg of goal body weight (about 0.7‚Äì1.0 g per lb). This boosts fullness and preserves muscle.
- Fat: 0.6‚Äì0.8 g per kg of goal body weight. Don‚Äôt go too low; fat supports hormones and satisfaction.
- Carbs: Fill the remaining calories with mostly high-fiber sources (whole grains, legumes, fruits, vegetables).

If you don‚Äôt want to track macros, use the plate method for each main meal:
- Half plate: non-starchy vegetables (leafy greens, broccoli, peppers, tomatoes, etc.).
- Quarter plate: lean protein (100‚Äì200 g cooked for most adults).
- Quarter plate: smart carbs (whole grains, beans, starchy veg, fruit).
- Add 1‚Äì2 thumbs of healthy fats (olive oil, avocado, nuts/seeds) if not included in cooking.

3) Structure your day
- 2‚Äì4 meals per day works; pick a pattern you can stick to.
- Anchor each meal with 25‚Äì40 g protein and at least one high-fiber food.
- Hydration: target 2‚Äì3 liters water/day. Limit alcohol and sugary drinks.

4) What to eat more often
- Proteins: chicken/turkey breast, fish/shellfish, eggs/egg whites, Greek yogurt/skyr, cottage cheese, tofu/tempeh, lentils/beans, lean beef/pork, protein shakes if needed.
- High-fiber carbs: oats, quinoa, brown rice, whole-wheat bread/pasta, potatoes/sweet potatoes with skin, beans/lentils, fruit.
- Veggies: any non-starchy vegetables you enjoy‚Äîfresh, frozen, or canned (low-sodium).
- Fats: olive oil, avocado, nuts and seeds, olives, nut butters.

5) What to limit (not ban)
- Ultra-processed snacks/desserts, fried foods, heavy sauces, refined carbs, and alcohol. Enjoy occasionally, in planned portions.

6) Sample day menus

Option A (around 1600‚Äì1700 kcal; omnivore)
- Breakfast: Greek yogurt (1 cup) + berries (1 cup) + 2 tbsp chopped nuts + 1 tbsp chia. Coffee/tea.
- Lunch: Grilled chicken salad: mixed greens, cherry tomatoes, cucumbers, peppers, 4‚Äì6 oz chicken, 1/2 cup chickpeas, 1‚Äì2 tbsp olive oil‚Äìlemon dressing, whole-grain roll.
- Snack: Protein shake or cottage cheese (3/4 cup) + an apple.
- Dinner: Salmon (5‚Äì6 oz) + 1/2‚Äì3/4 cup cooked quinoa + roasted broccoli and carrots. Optional small square dark chocolate.

Option B (around 1600‚Äì1700 kcal; vegetarian)
- Breakfast: Protein oatmeal: 1/2 cup oats cooked in milk or soy milk, stir in 1 scoop protein powder, top with banana slices and cinnamon.
- Lunch: Lentil and veggie bowl: 1 cup cooked lentils, roasted mixed vegetables, 1/2 cup brown rice, tahini‚Äìlemon drizzle.
- Snack: Skyr or Greek-style plant yogurt + grapes; or hummus (1/4 cup) with carrots and peppers.
- Dinner: Tofu stir-fry: extra-firm tofu (6 oz), mixed vegetables, 1 tsp sesame oil + soy/garlic/ginger, served over 3/4 cup cooked jasmine or brown rice.

7) Easy meal templates and swaps
- Breakfast: eggs + veg + whole-grain toast; or smoothie (protein powder, frozen fruit, spinach, milk/soy milk, flax/chia).
- Lunch/dinner bowls: pick 1 protein + 1‚Äì2 cups veg + 1 fist-sized smart carb + 1‚Äì2 tbsp sauce (yogurt, tahini, salsa, pesto).
- Sandwich/wrap: whole-grain bread/wrap + lean protein + lots of veg + light spread; add fruit on the side.
- Cultural swaps: same structure works with dal + roti + sabzi; grilled fish + plantains + salad; stir-fry + rice; tacos with lean meat/beans + salsa + slaw.

8) Snack ideas (200 calories or less)
- Fruit + 10‚Äì15 nuts
- Cottage cheese or skyr + berries
- Protein shake + carrot sticks
- Hummus (2‚Äì3 tbsp) + raw veg
- Hard-boiled eggs (1‚Äì2) + cherry tomatoes

9) Grocery list starter
- Proteins: chicken breast, canned tuna/salmon, eggs, yogurt/skyr, tofu/tempeh, beans/lentils, lean ground meats.
- Carbs: oats, quinoa, brown rice, potatoes/sweet potatoes, whole-grain bread/tortillas, fruit (bananas, apples, berries).
- Veg: leafy greens, crucifers, peppers, onions, tomatoes, cucumbers, frozen mixed veg for convenience.
- Fats/extras: olive oil, avocado, nuts/seeds, nut butter, spices, lemon/lime, low-sugar sauces.

10) Habits that make the plan work
- Meal prep 1‚Äì2 times weekly: cook proteins and grains in bulk; chop veggies; portion snacks.
- Eat slowly and stop at satisfied, not stuffed. Use smaller plates and serve sauces on the side.
- Walking: aim for 7,000‚Äì10,000 steps/day if possible. Strength train 2‚Äì3 times per week to preserve muscle.
- Sleep 7‚Äì9 hours; manage stress (even brief breathwork or a 10-minute walk helps).

11) Tracking and adjusting
- Track body weight 3‚Äì4 mornings per week and use the weekly average. Also track a waist or hip measurement and how clothes fit.
- If progress stalls for 2‚Äì3 weeks, reduce your daily calories by 100‚Äì150 or add 10‚Äì15 minutes of activity most days.
- If you‚Äôre excessively hungry or fatigued, increase protein/fiber or slightly raise calories.

12) Eating out and social events
- Center the meal on lean protein and vegetables; order dressings/sauces on the side.
- Choose grilled, baked, or steamed options; swap fries for salad/veg when you can.
- Share desserts or choose a single treat; limit alcohol to 0‚Äì2 drinks and avoid sugary mixers.

Optional, generally safe supplements
- Whey or plant protein to help hit protein targets.
- Creatine monohydrate 3‚Äì5 g/day if you strength train.
- Fiber supplement (psyllium) if you struggle to hit 25‚Äì40 g/day from food.
- Check with a clinician if you have medical conditions or take medications.

If you share your age, weight, height, sex, and activity level, I can help estimate a personalized calorie and macro target and provide a 7-day meal plan tailored to your preferences (omnivore, vegetarian, vegan, cultural cuisines, budget, and time).

instruction:
Estimate how long it will take to complete the task.
Task: Building a website from scratch
response: The time it takes to build a website from scratch can vary greatly depending on several factors, including the complexity of the website, the level of customization required, the number of pages, the functionality and features required, and the experience and skill level of the developer or development team. On average, building a basic website from scratch can take anywhere from 2 to 4 weeks for a small to medium-sized site with basic functionality. More complex websites with advanced features and functionality, on the other hand, can take several months to complete.
generated_response:
Short answer: it depends on scope. Here are realistic ballpark ranges for common website types, assuming a single developer/designer and typical review cycles.

Typical timelines
- Simple brochure site (1‚Äì5 pages, no CMS, one contact form): 2‚Äì7 days (16‚Äì56 hours)
- Small business site (5‚Äì10 pages, responsive, basic SEO, CMS like WordPress, contact form): 2‚Äì4 weeks (60‚Äì160 hours)
- Blog/content site (custom theme, CMS, categories/tags, search, authoring workflow): 3‚Äì6 weeks (80‚Äì200 hours)
- Small e‚Äëcommerce (‚â§100 products, Shopify/WooCommerce, payments, tax/shipping, email): 4‚Äì8 weeks (120‚Äì240 hours)
- Custom web app/MVP (auth, dashboards, database, APIs): 8‚Äì16 weeks (240‚Äì640 hours)
- Enterprise/complex (multilingual, heavy integrations, high accessibility/compliance): 3‚Äì6+ months

Phase breakdown (typical ranges)
- Discovery and requirements: 1‚Äì5 days (more if multiple stakeholders)
- Information architecture and wireframes: 1‚Äì5 days
- Visual design (style, components, key pages): 2‚Äì10 days
- Front‚Äëend development (responsive layouts, components): 3‚Äì15 days
- CMS/back‚Äëend setup (content models, custom fields, editor experience): 2‚Äì10 days
- Features/integrations (forms, search, payments, CRM, analytics): 1‚Äì10 days
- Content production/migration (copy, images, media): 2‚Äì15 days if not already ready; near‚Äëzero if fully prepared

instruction: What are the ingredients for a Chocolate Chip Cookie recipe?
response:
Here is a list of ingredients for making Chocolate Chip Cookies:

- 2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour
- 1 tsp baking soda
- 1 tsp salt
- 1 cup unsalted butter, softened to room temperature
- 3/4 cup white sugar
- 3/4 cup brown sugar
- 2 large eggs
- 1 tsp pure vanilla extract
- 2 cups semisweet chocolate chips
- Optional: 1 cup chopped nuts (such as walnuts or pecans)

These ingredients are the basic essentials for making traditional chocolate chip cookies. However, you can also add other ingredients to the recipe to suit your personal tastes or dietary preferences, such as using coconut oil instead of butter, or adding oats or raisins for an extra texture/flavor.

instruction: Collect 5 interesting facts about the US Capitol building.
response:
1. The United States Capitol is home to the United States Congress and the seat of the legislative branch of the Federal Government, located on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C. It was completed in the year 1800.

2. The Capitol building was designed by William Thornton, a physician by trade, after President George Washington issued a call for designs in 1792. Thornton won the competition and received a prize of $500 and a city lot for his design.

3. The building's iconic rotunda, which stands 180 feet high, features a fresco painted by Constantino Brumidi, known as the "Apotheosis of Washington." It portrays Washington sitting amongst the gods of classical mythology.

4. During the War of 1812, the Capitol was burned by British forces, along with several other government buildings in Washington, D.C. After the war, reconstruction of the building began, and it was restored and expanded over the next several decades.

5. The United States Capitol has a total floor area of about 16.5 acres, with nearly 540 rooms and 658 windows. The building is home to several works of art, including sculptures, frescoes, and paintings, as well as the National Statuary Hall Collection, which features 100 statues of individuals from each state.
generated_response:
- George Washington laid the Capitol‚Äôs cornerstone on September 18, 1793, in a Masonic ceremony. The exact location of that original cornerstone was lost during later expansions and renovations.
- British troops set the Capitol ablaze during the War of 1812 (August 24, 1814), gutting interiors. A sudden storm helped extinguish the fires, and reconstruction‚Äîled largely by Benjamin Henry Latrobe and Charles Bulfinch‚Äîfollowed in the years after.
- The familiar dome is cast iron, not stone. Built from 1855 to 1866‚Äîlargely during the Civil War‚Äîit is crowned by the 19-foot-6-inch, ~15,000-pound Statue of Freedom (installed in 1863). Philip Reid, an enslaved artisan, played a crucial role in casting the statue.
- The Capitol once housed all three branches of government: the Supreme Court met there from 1800 until 1935, when it moved into its own building. The Old Supreme Court Chamber and Old Senate Chamber can still be visited.
- Beneath the Rotunda is the Capitol Crypt, originally intended as George Washington‚Äôs tomb. He chose to be buried at Mount Vernon, so the crypt remains empty; the Rotunda above has since become the nation‚Äôs most prominent space for lying in state or honor.

instruction: Generate a creative non-fiction story about a newly discovered species of animal.
response:
In the depths of the Amazon rainforest, a new species of animal was discovered. It was something so unique and distinct, that the scientists who stumbled upon it couldn't believe their eyes.

The animal was first spotted by a group of explorers who were traversing through the dense jungle, studying the rich biodiversity of the region. It was a small creature, no bigger than an average-sized cat, and it had a body covered in soft, silky fur. Its tail was long and bushy, and its ears were perky and alert.

But what made this animal truly extraordinary were its wings. Yes, wings! At first, the explorers thought they were hallucinating. Animals with fur didn't have wings, or did they? Yet there it was, perched on a tree branch, its wings gently flapping in the breeze.

It took a few moments for the group to compose themselves, and when they did, they knew they had stumbled upon something amazing. They quickly set up their equipment, and began taking notes, snapping pictures, and capturing footage of this remarkable creature.

They observed its behavior, noting how it would glide from tree to tree, hunting for insects and small fruits. Its wings were powerful, yet silent, allowing it to move gracefully through the air.

As the days passed, the scientists learned more and more about this newly discovered species. They named it the "winged cat" due to its resemblance to a feline and its unique flying abilities.

News of the winged cat quickly spread, and soon people from all over the world were traveling to the Amazon to catch a glimpse of this remarkable creature. It became a symbol of wonder and hope, a reminder that there is still so much left to discover and explore in our vast and beautiful world.

The winged cat became a beloved inhabitant of the jungle, protected and cherished by all who knew of it. And for the explorers who first discovered it, it would always hold a special place in their hearts, a testament to the endless surprises and wonders that our planet has to offer.
generated_response:
The high forest begins where breath goes thin. We had driven into the Andes until the road forgot what it meant to be straight, then shouldered packs and moved upward into the cloud forest, where trees wear moss like fur and orchids sit in the crooks of branches with the certainty of old neighbors. The air smelled of wet bark and cold stone. When the wind came in from the Pacific, it laid down a sheet of mist so thick the world went soft, edges erased. It felt like walking into a story half-told.

We were chasing a rumor that had turned into a hypothesis, then a paper trail of bones. In climate-controlled rooms far from here, drawers of museum specimens had been pulled: narrow skulls, careful labels, skins flattened into history. On the tags the animals were called olingos‚Äîknown members of the raccoon family‚Äîbut the measurements kept refusing to align. The teeth were finer, the skull slightly shorter, the pelage softer and more reddish. There were genetic hints too, whispers on sequencing gels that said separate lineage, smaller cousin. Years earlier, one had passed through several North American zoos, classified as an olingo and destined to fail at breeding because no mate was ever quite the same. The animal‚Äîsmall, nocturnal, slightly out of place‚Äîhad traveled in circles around the truth of its own name.

Names matter in the forest. They are a way of saying we see you, of fastening care to a living thing. People living along the edges of the cloud forests spoke casually of a little ‚Äúolingo,‚Äù one that liked fruit and kept to the high canopy. Field biologists listened, set camera traps, followed habits like breadcrumbs. The animal was not unknown; it was simply misfiled, as if the world had let it slip behind a cabinet where no one swept for decades. Discovery is often not invention but rearrangement, a shift in the way the mind stacks what it has and then, finally, recognizes a pattern.

At dusk we tied a few pieces of sweet, overripe guava to a branch opposite our blind and settled onto damp ground. Nights here rise differently than in the lowlands. The forest doesn‚Äôt darken so much as it gathers itself, weaving a deeper textile of leaves and fog around your ears. Glass frogs go glassy, hummingbird hearts slow, and the long-tailed mice enunciate a different syllable in their running.

It came like a small wind. We saw movement first‚Äîrust in motion, a soft, careful weight settling onto a branch as if the branch were old, affectionate furniture. It was not fear but consideration. The animal‚Äôs fur caught what little light was left with a quiet glow, the color of a sunset that decided to stay. Its face, rounded and inquisitive, belonged to a lineage easily mistaken for cuddly if you didn‚Äôt know the story of teeth. It weighed about as much as a paperback book, a little over two pounds, and its tail‚Äîlush, balancing‚Äîwas nearly the length of its body. A carnivore, yes, if you listen only to the family tree, but in practice a frugivore with a taste for flowers and insects. It moved in a braided rhythm of hands and tail, the way the canopy teaches an animal to measure distance without falling.

Some science arrives dressed in press releases. ‚ÄúFirst new carnivore discovered in the Americas in more than three decades‚Äù was the tidy phrase that followed when this animal received its due: Bassaricyon neblina, the olinguito, the diminutive olingo of the mist. Neblina‚ÄîSpanish for fog‚Äîwas a name like home, and it wasn‚Äôt chosen casually. This species lives where clouds happen to the forest, between roughly 5,000 and 9,000 feet in Ecuador and Colombia, where the night wraps around branches and everything you can hold in your head feels briefly provisional. The olinguito likely had been here long before our field team and our taxonomies, riding and re-riding branches, raising young in tree hollows, eating small fruits with a careful mouth, watching the occasional human pass beneath like a rumor coursing through bracken.

We watched it from our blind‚Äîthe way it assessed the guava, the way its hands, in their way, knew fruit. There are certain moments in the field when the world acquires a new contour, a thin line added to a map that was never complete. This wasn‚Äôt the shock of a giant squid breaching; it was the quiet satisfaction of a missing word finally spoken. You could feel the rooms far away where drawers had been opened and data logged, and then backtrack to the slope where moisture is definition and the night is busy with the work of staying alive.

A discovery like this is always a braid: a museum, a field, a community that already had observed and named in its own terms, a lab where bone lengths and DNA segments make their case. Later, the paper would show holotypes and measurements, ranges and differences significant enough to merit a line in the family tree. It would argue for conservation, because habitat loss is not theoretical in the Andes. The cloud forests here are old and netlike, and when you cut a hole in a net, the effect ripples outward. Coffee and cattle push up the slopes; roads write new scar lines across the green; climate rearranges the distribution of mist itself. If the olinguito has a prayer, it lives in how we decide which names compel protection.

It finished the fruit and looked out from its branch with a gaze that didn‚Äôt flatten into myth. There is a way animals watch you when they expect you to break a branch or leave a scent that matters, and then there is the way they watch when you are simply another variable, one more moving part in a landscape that has always been complex. The olinguito‚Äôs eyes were dark and steady. It lifted, flowed, disappeared as if it had turned into another part of the fog.

We stayed long after. The forest has its own editorial standards. It will allow you a sighting and then insist you sit within its syntax and accept the chance that you won‚Äôt see another. Later, back at camp, we wrote notes that felt like handholds on a steep thought: time, elevation, behavior, diet cues, canopy structure. Someone drew a little face in the margin‚Äîround ears, big eyes, the tail like a flag. On the radio there was a report of rain moving in from the west, and on the far ridge the clouds lowered in a ceremony that felt both ordinary and enormous.

What does it mean to discover a species now, in the century of satellites and global search engines? It means the world remains bigger than the grid, that there are folds in the map where life continues to evolve without our supervision. It means that taxonomy‚Äîthe science of naming‚Äîis also a story about humility, about how even a small nocturnal mammal can evade our classification because we are busy elsewhere. It means admitting that local knowledge is not a footnote; it is a chapter, sometimes the one that gets us to the right page.

The next morning we moved higher into the forest, following a ridge that offered a window between curtains of trees. Hummingbirds stitched the air with their needle beaks and impossible wings, and somewhere above a troop of woolly monkeys sent down bits of leaf like confetti. In daylight, the olinguito is a rumor you cannot make into fact, at least not easily. But everything it requires is visible: bromeliads holding cups of water for insects, tree ferns layered like the racks in an old archive, figs swelling, a mild, persistent rain. Each component is a sentence in a paragraph that sustains a life.

That afternoon we hiked to a village where the forest thins and people keep to steep plots carved into the slope. A woman pointed to a tree near her house and described‚Äîwithout ceremony‚Äîhow a little animal visits at night to take the fruit when it is sweetest and that you can hear it chewing if you stand very still and the road quiets. She wasn‚Äôt wrong. Her name for it wasn‚Äôt ours, but I think now hers was more accurate, because it was not an introduction but an acknowledgement. It had never been unknown; it had been unroomed in our architecture of knowledge.

In the museum, the drawers close with a particular sound, metal on wood, quieting specimens until the next person comes to open them. In the forest, edges close with mist. Between those closures lives a little bear-faced carnivore that prefers fruit and high branches and night, and it is new to us in the way grandparents are new to children‚Äîalready here, already woven into the fabric, waiting for our recognition. The olinguito slipped into our vocabulary and into the journals, and with that the obligation began. We had held it long enough to say its name. Now the work was to keep its forest a place where the fog can carry a small life from one branch to another, and where discovery can remain a story about the great, generous unfinishedness of the world.

instruction:
Describe the idea behind this quote.
"The best and most beautiful things in the world cannot be seen or even touched ‚Äì they must be felt with the heart." -Helen Keller
response: The quote by Helen Keller emphasizes the idea that our most profound experiences and emotions lie beyond the realm of our physical senses. It suggests that some of the most valuable things in life, such as love, compassion, and inner peace, cannot be perceived through the mere act of seeing or touching. Instead, they must be experienced deeply within ourselves through our emotions and intuition, which are connected to our hearts. In other words, some of the richest aspects of life are not tangible or material, but rather are internal and intangible. Hence, it's important to cultivate our inner world and connect with our feelings, as this is where true beauty and fulfillment resides.
generated_response:
Helen Keller is pointing out that the deepest forms of beauty and value in life aren‚Äôt physical objects or sights we can observe. They are intangible experiences and qualities‚Äîthings we know through feeling, not through the senses or even pure reasoning. ‚ÄúThe heart‚Äù here is a metaphor for our inner life: empathy, love, intuition, and the capacity to be moved.

The quote carries special weight coming from Keller, who was both blind and deaf. Her life showed that meaning and beauty don‚Äôt depend on seeing or touching; they spring from connection, compassion, purpose, and the inner responses we have to the world and to each other.

Examples of such ‚Äúfelt‚Äù beauties include:
- Love and trust between people
- Kindness, forgiveness, and courage
- A sense of belonging or being truly understood
- Wonder, hope, and gratitude
- Purpose and moral integrity

The idea challenges materialism and surface-level judgments. It suggests that a good life is measured less by what we can acquire or observe and more by the quality of our relationships, the depth of our character, and the richness of our inner experiences. It‚Äôs an invitation to cultivate empathy and attentiveness so we don‚Äôt miss the most beautiful parts of being human.

instruction: Give an example of when AI can be used to improve healthcare.
response:
One example of how AI can be used to improve healthcare is through the use of machine learning algorithms to analyze vast amounts of medical data and identify patterns, correlations and anomalies that would otherwise go unnoticed by traditional analysis. For instance, AI can be used to develop predictive models to identify individuals at high risk of certain chronic diseases earlier in their lifetimes, allowing for earlier diagnosis and treatment.
 
Another application of AI in healthcare is the development of more advanced imaging and diagnostic tools that utilize computer vision to interpret medical scans more accurately, allowing doctors to identify and diagnose conditions such as tumors or abnormalities more effectively. This could lead to earlier detection of diseases and more effective treatments. 

Other exciting areas where AI can improve healthcare include drug discovery and development by using AI technology to analyze large datasets and identify new candidate drugs; improve patient outcomes by predicting complications, readmissions or postoperative infections; and streamlining electronic health record management by employing natural language processing to extract valuable data from unstructured data sources like doctor‚Äôs notes and patient‚Äôs medical histories. Overall, the potential of AI to improve healthcare is vast, and its use is expected to continue expanding in the future.
generated_response:
Example: Automated diabetic retinopathy screening in primary care

- What happens: A patient with diabetes gets retinal photos taken with a small fundus camera during a routine visit. An AI model analyzes the images on the spot and flags whether there are signs of more-than-mild retinopathy.
- Why it helps: Patients get immediate results and, if needed, are referred to an eye specialist sooner. Clinics without on-site ophthalmologists can still screen effectively, raising screening rates and catching disease earlier, which reduces vision loss.
- Additional benefits: Frees specialist time for higher-risk cases, standardizes image interpretation, and supports care in underserved areas.
- Safeguards: Ensure image quality checks, human oversight for positives and edge cases, integration with EHR workflows, and monitoring for bias and privacy compliance.

High-level view (next 3‚Äì6 months)

  - International profitability trajectory (Europe, Japan, India) as a secondary margin lever.
- Advertising
  - Core Sponsored ads growth and measurement enhancements.
  - Prime Video ads ramp: ad load, CPMs, and contribution to operating income. Sports (e.g., NFL) inventory monetization.
- Regulation and legal
  - FTC and EU cases: any developments that could affect marketplace pricing, Prime bundling, or business practices.
- Macro and rates
  - A higher 10-year yield typically pressures long-duration growth stocks‚Äô multiples; a benign rates backdrop helps.

Valuation framing (not a price target)
- Investors often view Amazon as a sum of parts: AWS (dominant cloud with AI optionality), Ads (high-margin flywheel on retail and video), and Retail/Logistics (improving efficiency and moat via fulfillment).
- Near-term multiple is most sensitive to changes in AWS growth/margins and the durability of consolidated operating margin expansion. Rising capex for AI can compress near-term free cash flow but may be rewarded if tied to visible demand.

Potential scenarios (next 3‚Äì6 months)
- Bull case
  - AWS posts clear re-acceleration with AI-related wins and improving backlog; Ads grows strongly; North America retail margins hold or expand despite seasonality.
  - Market looks through higher capex; consolidated operating income surprises to the upside.
  - Outcome: Stock outperforms and can grind higher as estimates get revised up.
- Base case
  - AWS growth improves gradually; Ads solid; retail margins steady but not expanding meaningfully. Capex rises but is framed as demand-driven.
  - Outcome: Stock tracks earnings estimate revisions; sideways-to-up with volatility around earnings.
- Bear case
  - AWS growth underwhelms or AI monetization is slower; regulatory headlines increase perceived risk; consumer spending softens and retail margins compress.
  - Outcome: Multiple compresses; stock underperforms into the next print.

Technical considerations (if you follow charts)
- Watch the 50- and 200-day moving averages, prior earnings gaps, and relative strength versus the broader tech complex. Options-implied moves into earnings can frame expected volatility. I can help interpret these if you share current levels.

What to monitor in upcoming reports
- AWS revenue growth rate, operating margin, capex and power/capacity commentary, and backlog/remaining performance obligations.
- Advertising services growth and detail on Prime Video ad monetization.
- North America and International segment operating margins; unit cost per package.
- Free cash flow and any updates on buybacks or capital allocation.
- Regulatory updates affecting marketplace fees or Prime bundling.

Bottom line
- In the near term, the path of least resistance for the stock is tied to evidence of AWS re-acceleration and sustained margin improvement across the portfolio. Strong AI demand signals and resilient advertising could support upside even amid higher capex, while disappointments on AWS or negative regulatory developments are the key downside risks.

This is general information, not investment advice. If you can share the latest earnings highlights or your time horizon (trader vs. long-term holder), I can refine the outlook and discuss potential entries, risk management, and catalysts in more detail.

instruction: List 5 tips for improving public speaking skills.
response:
1. **Practice:** The more you practice, the more confident and comfortable you will become with the material you are presenting. Try to rehearse your speech or presentation several times, either on your own or in front of someone you trust who can give you constructive feedback.

2. **Know your audience:** Understanding your audience is crucial for delivering an effective speech. Take some time to research your audience and tailor your message to their interests and needs.

3. **Engage with your audience:** Make eye contact, smile, and use gestures to engage with your audience. This helps to establish a connection and can make you appear more confident and likable.

4. **Speak clearly and at a good pace:** Make sure to enunciate your words and speak at a pace that is easy for your audience to follow. Avoid speaking too quickly, as this can make it difficult for your audience to keep up with what you are saying.

5. **Use visual aids:** Using visual aids such as slides or props can help to reinforce your message and keep your audience engaged. Use them sparingly and make sure they are relevant to your presentation.
generated_response:
- Clarify your core message and structure: know your audience, define the takeaway, and outline with clear signposts (intro, key points, conclusion).
- Practice deliberately: rehearse aloud, record yourself, time it, and refine based on feedback; simulate the actual setting when possible.
- Strengthen delivery: vary pace and volume, use purposeful pauses, and articulate clearly; keep open posture, natural gestures, and consistent eye contact.
- Manage nerves: use slow breathing (e.g., box breathing), brief visualization, and a pre-talk warm-up; arrive early to test equipment and the room.
- Engage the room: start with a hook, use stories and examples, ask rhetorical or real questions, and adjust based on audience reactions.

instruction: For what value of k does the line represented by the equation -1/2-2kx = 5y contain the point (1/4,-6)?
response: To find the value of k that makes the line -1/2 - 2kx = 5y contain the point (1/4, -6), we plug in x = 1/4 and y = -6. This gives us the equation -1/2 - k/2 = 5(-6). Simplifying this equation, we get -1 - k = -60. Solving for k, we find that k = 59. Therefore, the value of k that makes the line contain the point (1/4, -6) is 59.
